speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A room in the castle.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Enter KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and Attendants

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Moreover that we much did long to see you,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The need we have to use you did provoke

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Our hasty sending. Something have you heard

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Of Hamlet's transformation; so call it,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Sith nor the exterior nor the inward man

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Resembles that it was. What it should be,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: More than his father's death, that thus hath put him

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: So much from the understanding of himself,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: I cannot dream of: I entreat you both,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That, being of so young days brought up with him,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And sith so neighbour'd to his youth and havior,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Some little time: so by your companies

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: So much as from occasion you may glean,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Whether aught, to us unknown, afflicts him thus,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: That, open'd, lies within our remedy.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Good gentlemen, he hath much talk'd of you;

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And sure I am two men there are not living

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: To whom he more adheres. If it will please you

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: To show us so much gentry and good will

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: As to expend your time with us awhile,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: For the supply and profit of our hope,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Your visitation shall receive such thanks

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: As fits a king's remembrance.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Both your majesties

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Put your dread pleasures more into command

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Than to entreaty.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: But we both obey,

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: And here give up ourselves, in the full bent

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: To lay our service freely at your feet,

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: To be commanded.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz:

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And I beseech you instantly to visit

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: My too much changed son. Go, some of you,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: Heavens make our presence and our practises

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: Pleasant and helpful to him!

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Ay, amen!

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and some Attendants

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Enter POLONIUS

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The ambassadors from Norway, my good lord,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Are joyfully return'd.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Thou still hast been the father of good news.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Have I, my lord? I assure my good liege,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I hold my duty, as I hold my soul,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Both to my God and to my gracious king:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And I do think, or else this brain of mine

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Hunts not the trail of policy so sure

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As it hath used to do, that I have found

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: O, speak of that; that do I long to hear.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Give first admittance to the ambassadors;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exit POLONIUS

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: The head and source of all your son's distemper.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: I doubt it is no other but the main;

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: His father's death, and our o'erhasty marriage.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Well, we shall sift him.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Re-enter POLONIUS, with VOLTIMAND and CORNELIUS

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Welcome, my good friends!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Say, Voltimand, what from our brother Norway?

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Most fair return of greetings and desires.

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Upon our first, he sent out to suppress

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: His nephew's levies; which to him appear'd

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack;

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: But, better look'd into, he truly found

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: It was against your highness: whereat grieved,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: That so his sickness, age and impotence

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys;

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Makes vow before his uncle never more

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: To give the assay of arms against your majesty.

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: And his commission to employ those soldiers,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: So levied as before, against the Polack:

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: With an entreaty, herein further shown,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Giving a paper

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: That it might please you to give quiet pass

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: Through your dominions for this enterprise,

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: On such regards of safety and allowance

speaker: VOLTIMAND
text_entry: As therein are set down.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: It likes us well;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: And at our more consider'd time well read,

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Answer, and think upon this business.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Go to your rest; at night we'll feast together:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Most welcome home!

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt VOLTIMAND and CORNELIUS

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This business is well ended.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: My liege, and madam, to expostulate

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What majesty should be, what duty is,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Why day is day, night night, and time is time,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Were nothing but to waste night, day and time.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I will be brief: your noble son is mad:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mad call I it; for, to define true madness,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What is't but to be nothing else but mad?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But let that go.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: More matter, with less art.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Madam, I swear I use no art at all.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That he is mad, 'tis true: 'tis true 'tis pity;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And pity 'tis 'tis true: a foolish figure;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But farewell it, for I will use no art.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mad let us grant him, then: and now remains

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That we find out the cause of this effect,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or rather say, the cause of this defect,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: For this effect defective comes by cause:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. Perpend.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I have a daughter--have while she is mine--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Who, in her duty and obedience, mark,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Hath given me this: now gather, and surmise.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'To the celestial and my soul's idol, the most

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: beautified Ophelia,'--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase; 'beautified' is

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: a vile phrase: but you shall hear. Thus:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'In her excellent white bosom, these,  and c.'

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Came this from Hamlet to her?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Good madam, stay awhile; I will be faithful.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'Doubt thou the stars are fire;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Doubt that the sun doth move;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Doubt truth to be a liar;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But never doubt I love.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I have not art to reckon my groans: but that

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I love thee best, O most best, believe it. Adieu.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'Thine evermore most dear lady, whilst

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: this machine is to him, HAMLET.'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This, in obedience, hath my daughter shown me,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And more above, hath his solicitings,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As they fell out by time, by means and place,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: All given to mine ear.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: But how hath she

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Received his love?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What do you think of me?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: As of a man faithful and honourable.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I would fain prove so. But what might you think,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: When I had seen this hot love on the wing--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: As I perceived it, I must tell you that,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Before my daughter told me--what might you,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or my dear majesty your queen here, think,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: If I had play'd the desk or table-book,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Or look'd upon this love with idle sight;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What might you think? No, I went round to work,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And my young mistress thus I did bespeak:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'Lord Hamlet is a prince, out of thy star;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This must not be:' and then I precepts gave her,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That she should lock herself from his resort,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Admit no messengers, receive no tokens.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Which done, she took the fruits of my advice;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And he, repulsed--a short tale to make--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Into the madness wherein now he raves,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And all we mourn for.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Do you think 'tis this?

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: It may be, very likely.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Hath there been such a time--I'd fain know that--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That I have positively said 'Tis so,'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: When it proved otherwise?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Not that I know.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: [Pointing to his head and shoulder]

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Take this from this, if this be otherwise:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: If circumstances lead me, I will find

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Within the centre.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: How may we try it further?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: You know, sometimes he walks four hours together

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Here in the lobby.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: So he does indeed.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: At such a time I'll loose my daughter to him:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Be you and I behind an arras then;

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Mark the encounter: if he love her not

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: And be not from his reason fall'n thereon,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Let me be no assistant for a state,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: But keep a farm and carters.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: We will try it.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: But, look, where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Away, I do beseech you, both away:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I'll board him presently.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Exeunt KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, and Attendants

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Enter HAMLET, reading

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: O, give me leave:

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: How does my good Lord Hamlet?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Well, God-a-mercy.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Do you know me, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Excellent well; you are a fishmonger.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Not I, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then I would you were so honest a man.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Honest, my lord!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ay, sir; to be honest, as this world goes, is to be

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: one man picked out of ten thousand.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That's very true, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: god kissing carrion,--Have you a daughter?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I have, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let her not walk i' the sun: conception is a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: blessing: but not as your daughter may conceive.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Friend, look to 't.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  How say you by that? Still harping on my

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: daughter: yet he knew me not at first; he said I

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: was a fishmonger: he is far gone, far gone: and

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: truly in my youth I suffered much extremity for

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: love; very near this. I'll speak to him again.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What do you read, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Words, words, words.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What is the matter, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Between who?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: I mean, the matter that you read, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Slanders, sir: for the satirical rogue says here

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: that old men have grey beards, that their faces are

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: wrinkled, their eyes purging thick amber and

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: plum-tree gum and that they have a plentiful lack of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: wit, together with most weak hams: all which, sir,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: though I most powerfully and potently believe, yet

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I hold it not honesty to have it thus set down, for

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: yourself, sir, should be old as I am, if like a crab

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: you could go backward.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  Though this be madness, yet there is method

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: in 't. Will you walk out of the air, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Into my grave.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Indeed, that is out o' the air.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Aside

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: How pregnant sometimes his replies are! a happiness

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: that often madness hits on, which reason and sanity

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: could not so prosperously be delivered of. I will

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: leave him, and suddenly contrive the means of

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: meeting between him and my daughter.--My honourable

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: lord, I will most humbly take my leave of you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: You cannot, sir, take from me any thing that I will

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: more willingly part withal: except my life, except

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: my life, except my life.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Fare you well, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: These tedious old fools!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Enter ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: You go to seek the Lord Hamlet; there he is.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: [To POLONIUS]  God save you, sir!

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Exit POLONIUS

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: My honoured lord!

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: My most dear lord!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: My excellent good friends! How dost thou,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Guildenstern? Ah, Rosencrantz! Good lads, how do ye both?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: As the indifferent children of the earth.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: Happy, in that we are not over-happy;

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: On fortune's cap we are not the very button.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nor the soles of her shoe?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Neither, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: her favours?

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: 'Faith, her privates we.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: In the secret parts of fortune? O, most true; she

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: is a strumpet. What's the news?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: None, my lord, but that the world's grown honest.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then is doomsday near: but your news is not true.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let me question more in particular: what have you,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: my good friends, deserved at the hands of fortune,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: that she sends you to prison hither?

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: Prison, my lord!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Denmark's a prison.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Then is the world one.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A goodly one; in which there are many confines,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: wards and dungeons, Denmark being one o' the worst.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: We think not so, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why, then, 'tis none to you; for there is nothing

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: either good or bad, but thinking makes it so: to me

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: it is a prison.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Why then, your ambition makes it one; 'tis too

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: narrow for your mind.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O God, I could be bounded in a nut shell and count

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: myself a king of infinite space, were it not that I

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: have bad dreams.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: Which dreams indeed are ambition, for the very

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A dream itself is but a shadow.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: quality that it is but a shadow's shadow.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: outstretched heroes the beggars' shadows. Shall we

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: to the court? for, by my fay, I cannot reason.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: We'll wait upon you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: No such matter: I will not sort you with the rest

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: of my servants, for, to speak to you like an honest

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: man, I am most dreadfully attended. But, in the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: beaten way of friendship, what make you at Elsinore?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: To visit you, my lord; no other occasion.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: thank you: and sure, dear friends, my thanks are

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: too dear a halfpenny. Were you not sent for? Is it

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: your own inclining? Is it a free visitation? Come,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: deal justly with me: come, come; nay, speak.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: What should we say, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why, any thing, but to the purpose. You were sent

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: for; and there is a kind of confession in your looks

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: which your modesties have not craft enough to colour:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I know the good king and queen have sent for you.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: To what end, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That you must teach me. But let me conjure you, by

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: love, and by what more dear a better proposer could

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: charge you withal, be even and direct with me,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: whether you were sent for, or no?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: [Aside to GUILDENSTERN]  What say you?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: [Aside]  Nay, then, I have an eye of you.--If you

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: love me, hold not off.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: My lord, we were sent for.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I will tell you why; so shall my anticipation

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: prevent your discovery, and your secrecy to the king

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: and queen moult no feather. I have of late--but

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: wherefore I know not--lost all my mirth, forgone all

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: custom of exercises; and indeed it goes so heavily

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: with my disposition that this goodly frame, the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: earth, seems to me a sterile promontory, this most

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: excellent canopy, the air, look you, this brave

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: o'erhanging firmament, this majestical roof fretted

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: with golden fire, why, it appears no other thing to

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: me than a foul and pestilent congregation of vapours.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What a piece of work is a man! how noble in reason!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: how infinite in faculty! in form and moving how

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: express and admirable! in action how like an angel!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: in apprehension how like a god! the beauty of the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: world! the paragon of animals! And yet, to me,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: what is this quintessence of dust? man delights not

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: me: no, nor woman neither, though by your smiling

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: you seem to say so.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: My lord, there was no such stuff in my thoughts.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why did you laugh then, when I said 'man delights not me'?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: To think, my lord, if you delight not in man, what

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: lenten entertainment the players shall receive from

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: you: we coted them on the way; and hither are they

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: coming, to offer you service.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: He that plays the king shall be welcome; his majesty

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: shall have tribute of me; the adventurous knight

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: shall use his foil and target; the lover shall not

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: sigh gratis; the humourous man shall end his part

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: in peace; the clown shall make those laugh whose

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: lungs are tickled o' the sere; and the lady shall

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: say her mind freely, or the blank verse shall halt

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: for't. What players are they?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Even those you were wont to take delight in, the

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: tragedians of the city.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How chances it they travel? their residence, both

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: in reputation and profit, was better both ways.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: I think their inhibition comes by the means of the

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: late innovation.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: in the city? are they so followed?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: No, indeed, are they not.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How comes it? do they grow rusty?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Nay, their endeavour keeps in the wonted pace: but

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: there is, sir, an aery of children, little eyases,

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: that cry out on the top of question, and are most

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: tyrannically clapped for't: these are now the

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: fashion, and so berattle the common stages--so they

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: call them--that many wearing rapiers are afraid of

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: goose-quills and dare scarce come thither.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What, are they children? who maintains 'em? how are

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: they escoted? Will they pursue the quality no

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: longer than they can sing? will they not say

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: afterwards, if they should grow themselves to common

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: players--as it is most like, if their means are no

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: better--their writers do them wrong, to make them

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: exclaim against their own succession?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: 'Faith, there has been much to do on both sides; and

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: the nation holds it no sin to tarre them to

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: controversy: there was, for a while, no money bid

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: for argument, unless the poet and the player went to

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: cuffs in the question.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Is't possible?

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: O, there has been much throwing about of brains.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Do the boys carry it away?

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Ay, that they do, my lord; Hercules and his load too.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: It is not very strange; for mine uncle is king of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Denmark, and those that would make mows at him while

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: my father lived, give twenty, forty, fifty, an

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: hundred ducats a-piece for his picture in little.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'Sblood, there is something in this more than

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: natural, if philosophy could find it out.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Flourish of trumpets within

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: There are the players.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore. Your hands,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: come then: the appurtenance of welcome is fashion

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: and ceremony: let me comply with you in this garb,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: lest my extent to the players, which, I tell you,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: must show fairly outward, should more appear like

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: entertainment than yours. You are welcome: but my

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: uncle-father and aunt-mother are deceived.

speaker: GUILDENSTERN
text_entry: In what, my dear lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I am but mad north-north-west: when the wind is

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: southerly I know a hawk from a handsaw.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Enter POLONIUS

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Well be with you, gentlemen!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Hark you, Guildenstern; and you too: at each ear a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: hearer: that great baby you see there is not yet

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: out of his swaddling-clouts.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Happily he's the second time come to them; for they

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: say an old man is twice a child.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I will prophesy he comes to tell me of the players;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: mark it. You say right, sir: o' Monday morning;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'twas so indeed.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: My lord, I have news to tell you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: My lord, I have news to tell you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: When Roscius was an actor in Rome,--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The actors are come hither, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Buz, buz!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Upon mine honour,--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Then came each actor on his ass,--

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: The best actors in the world, either for tragedy,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical,

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: comical-historical-pastoral, scene individable, or

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: poem unlimited: Seneca cannot be too heavy, nor

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Plautus too light. For the law of writ and the

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: liberty, these are the only men.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O Jephthah, judge of Israel, what a treasure hadst thou!

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What a treasure had he, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'One fair daughter and no more,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The which he loved passing well.'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  Still on my daughter.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Am I not i' the right, old Jephthah?

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: If you call me Jephthah, my lord, I have a daughter

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: that I love passing well.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nay, that follows not.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: What follows, then, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'As by lot, God wot,'

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: and then, you know,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'It came to pass, as most like it was,'--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: the first row of the pious chanson will show you

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: more; for look, where my abridgement comes.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Enter four or five Players

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: You are welcome, masters; welcome, all. I am glad

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: to see thee well. Welcome, good friends. O, my old

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: friend! thy face is valenced since I saw thee last:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: comest thou to beard me in Denmark? What, my young

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: lady and mistress! By'r lady, your ladyship is

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: nearer to heaven than when I saw you last, by the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: altitude of a chopine. Pray God, your voice, like

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: apiece of uncurrent gold, be not cracked within the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: ring. Masters, you are all welcome. We'll e'en

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: to't like French falconers, fly at any thing we see:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: we'll have a speech straight: come, give us a taste

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: of your quality; come, a passionate speech.

speaker: First Player
text_entry: What speech, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I heard thee speak me a speech once, but it was

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: never acted; or, if it was, not above once; for the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: play, I remember, pleased not the million; 'twas

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: caviare to the general: but it was--as I received

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: it, and others, whose judgments in such matters

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: cried in the top of mine--an excellent play, well

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: digested in the scenes, set down with as much

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: modesty as cunning. I remember, one said there

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: were no sallets in the lines to make the matter

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: savoury, nor no matter in the phrase that might

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: indict the author of affectation; but called it an

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: honest method, as wholesome as sweet, and by very

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: much more handsome than fine. One speech in it I

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: chiefly loved: 'twas Aeneas' tale to Dido; and

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: thereabout of it especially, where he speaks of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Priam's slaughter: if it live in your memory, begin

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: at this line: let me see, let me see--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'The rugged Pyrrhus, like the Hyrcanian beast,'--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: it is not so:--it begins with Pyrrhus:--

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'The rugged Pyrrhus, he whose sable arms,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Black as his purpose, did the night resemble

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: When he lay couched in the ominous horse,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Hath now this dread and black complexion smear'd

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With heraldry more dismal; head to foot

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Now is he total gules; horridly trick'd

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Baked and impasted with the parching streets,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That lend a tyrannous and damned light

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: To their lord's murder: roasted in wrath and fire,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And thus o'er-sized with coagulate gore,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With eyes like carbuncles, the hellish Pyrrhus

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Old grandsire Priam seeks.'

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: So, proceed you.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: 'Fore God, my lord, well spoken, with good accent and

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: good discretion.

speaker: First Player
text_entry: 'Anon he finds him

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Striking too short at Greeks; his antique sword,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Rebellious to his arm, lies where it falls,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Repugnant to command: unequal match'd,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Pyrrhus at Priam drives; in rage strikes wide;

speaker: First Player
text_entry: But with the whiff and wind of his fell sword

speaker: First Player
text_entry: The unnerved father falls. Then senseless Ilium,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Seeming to feel this blow, with flaming top

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Stoops to his base, and with a hideous crash

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Takes prisoner Pyrrhus' ear: for, lo! his sword,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Which was declining on the milky head

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Of reverend Priam, seem'd i' the air to stick:

speaker: First Player
text_entry: So, as a painted tyrant, Pyrrhus stood,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: And like a neutral to his will and matter,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Did nothing.

speaker: First Player
text_entry: But, as we often see, against some storm,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: A silence in the heavens, the rack stand still,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: The bold winds speechless and the orb below

speaker: First Player
text_entry: As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Doth rend the region, so, after Pyrrhus' pause,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Aroused vengeance sets him new a-work;

speaker: First Player
text_entry: And never did the Cyclops' hammers fall

speaker: First Player
text_entry: On Mars's armour forged for proof eterne

speaker: First Player
text_entry: With less remorse than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Now falls on Priam.

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Out, out, thou strumpet, Fortune! All you gods,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: In general synod 'take away her power;

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: As low as to the fiends!'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: This is too long.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: It shall to the barber's, with your beard. Prithee,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: say on: he's for a jig or a tale of bawdry, or he

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: sleeps: say on: come to Hecuba.

speaker: First Player
text_entry: 'But who, O, who had seen the mobled queen--'

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'The mobled queen?'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: That's good; 'mobled queen' is good.

speaker: First Player
text_entry: 'Run barefoot up and down, threatening the flames

speaker: First Player
text_entry: With bisson rheum; a clout upon that head

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Where late the diadem stood, and for a robe,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: About her lank and all o'er-teemed loins,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: A blanket, in the alarm of fear caught up;

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Who this had seen, with tongue in venom steep'd,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: 'Gainst Fortune's state would treason have

speaker: First Player
text_entry: pronounced:

speaker: First Player
text_entry: But if the gods themselves did see her then

speaker: First Player
text_entry: When she saw Pyrrhus make malicious sport

speaker: First Player
text_entry: In mincing with his sword her husband's limbs,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: The instant burst of clamour that she made,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Unless things mortal move them not at all,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Would have made milch the burning eyes of heaven,

speaker: First Player
text_entry: And passion in the gods.'

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Look, whether he has not turned his colour and has

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: tears in's eyes. Pray you, no more.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'Tis well: I'll have thee speak out the rest soon.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Good my lord, will you see the players well

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: bestowed? Do you hear, let them be well used; for

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: they are the abstract and brief chronicles of the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: time: after your death you were better have a bad

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: epitaph than their ill report while you live.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: My lord, I will use them according to their desert.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: God's bodykins, man, much better: use every man

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: after his desert, and who should 'scape whipping?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Use them after your own honour and dignity: the less

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: they deserve, the more merit is in your bounty.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Take them in.

speaker: LORD POLONIUS
text_entry: Come, sirs.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Follow him, friends: we'll hear a play to-morrow.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exit POLONIUS with all the Players but the First

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Dost thou hear me, old friend; can you play the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Murder of Gonzago?

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: We'll ha't to-morrow night. You could, for a need,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: study a speech of some dozen or sixteen lines, which

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I would set down and insert in't, could you not?

speaker: First Player
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Very well. Follow that lord; and look you mock him

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: not.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exit First Player

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: My good friends, I'll leave you till night: you are

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: welcome to Elsinore.

speaker: ROSENCRANTZ
text_entry: Good my lord!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ay, so, God be wi' ye;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Now I am alone.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O, what a rogue and peasant slave am I!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Is it not monstrous that this player here,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But in a fiction, in a dream of passion,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Could force his soul so to his own conceit

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That from her working all his visage wann'd,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Tears in his eyes, distraction in's aspect,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A broken voice, and his whole function suiting

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With forms to his conceit? and all for nothing!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For Hecuba!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What's Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That he should weep for her? What would he do,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Had he the motive and the cue for passion

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That I have? He would drown the stage with tears

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And cleave the general ear with horrid speech,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Make mad the guilty and appal the free,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Confound the ignorant, and amaze indeed

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The very faculties of eyes and ears. Yet I,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A dull and muddy-mettled rascal, peak,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Like John-a-dreams, unpregnant of my cause,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And can say nothing; no, not for a king,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Upon whose property and most dear life

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A damn'd defeat was made. Am I a coward?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Who calls me villain? breaks my pate across?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Plucks off my beard, and blows it in my face?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Tweaks me by the nose? gives me the lie i' the throat,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: As deep as to the lungs? who does me this?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'Swounds, I should take it: for it cannot be

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But I am pigeon-liver'd and lack gall

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: To make oppression bitter, or ere this

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I should have fatted all the region kites

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With this slave's offal: bloody, bawdy villain!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O, vengeance!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why, what an ass am I! This is most brave,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That I, the son of a dear father murder'd,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Must, like a whore, unpack my heart with words,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And fall a-cursing, like a very drab,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A scullion!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Fie upon't! foh! About, my brain! I have heard

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That guilty creatures sitting at a play

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Have by the very cunning of the scene

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Been struck so to the soul that presently

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: They have proclaim'd their malefactions;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: With most miraculous organ. I'll have these players

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Play something like the murder of my father

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Before mine uncle: I'll observe his looks;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I'll tent him to the quick: if he but blench,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I know my course. The spirit that I have seen

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: May be the devil: and the devil hath power

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: To assume a pleasing shape; yea, and perhaps

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Out of my weakness and my melancholy,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: As he is very potent with such spirits,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Abuses me to damn me: I'll have grounds

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: More relative than this: the play 's the thing

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exit
